title-group.article-title: Effects of methylphenidate on basic and higher-order oculomotor functions

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Psychology, McGill University, Montreal, QC, Canada
2Faculty of Psychology, University of Munich, Munich, Germany
3Department of Psychiatry, McGill University, Montreal, QC, Canada
4Douglas Mental Health University Institute, Montreal, QC, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Gillian O’Driscoll, Department of Psychology, McGill University, 1205 Dr Penfield Ave., Montreal, QC, H3Z 2G3, Canada Email: gillian@hebb.psych.mcgill.ca

abstract.p: Eye movements are sensitive indicators of pharmacological effects on sensorimotor and cognitive processing. Methylphenidate (MPH) is one of the most prescribed medications in psychiatry. It is increasingly used as a cognitive enhancer by healthy individuals. However, little is known of its effect on healthy cognition. Here we used oculomotor tests to evaluate the effects of MPH on basic oculomotor and executive functions. Twenty-nine males were given 20mg of MPH orally in a double-blind placebo-controlled crossover design. Participants performed visually-guided saccades, sinusoidal smooth pursuit, predictive saccades and antisaccades one hour post-capsule administration. Heart rate and blood pressure were assessed prior to capsule administration, and again before and after task performance. Visually-guided saccade latency decreased with MPH (p<0.004). Smooth pursuit gain increased on MPH (p<0.001) and number of saccades during pursuit decreased (p<0.001). Proportion of predictive saccades increased on MPH (p<0.004), specifically in conditions with predictable timing. Peak velocity of predictive saccades increased with MPH (p<0.01). Antisaccade errors and latency were unaffected. Physiological variables were also unaffected. The effects on visually-guided saccade latency and peak velocity are consistent with MPH effects on dopamine in basal ganglia. The improvements in predictive saccade conditions and smooth pursuit suggest effects on timing functions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Methylphenidate (MPH) is a psychostimulant whose major actions include increasing the availability of dopamine (DA) and noradrenaline (NA) by blocking the DA transporter (Heal et al., 2009). MPH is the primary treatment for Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) (Dodson, 2005), where its cognitive-enhancing properties have been documented (Kurscheidt et al., 2008; Pietrzak et al., 2006 but see Bidwell et al., 2011; Swanson et al., 2011).

Recently, there has been an increase in the off-label use of MPH as a cognitive enhancer in healthy individuals (Advokat et al., 2008; Wilens et al., 2008), but empirical support for cognitive enhancing effects in this population is relatively sparse. A recent review of the small available literature showed reliable effects in healthy individuals only on memory (Repantis et al., 2010).

Eye movement tasks are well suited to examine drug effects (Reilly et al., 2008). Their neurophysiological and neurochemical bases have been well established in non-human primates (Ilg and Thier, 2008; Johnston and Everling, 2008; Kori et al., 1995), and neuroimaging studies have identified homologous regions in the human brain that subserve these tasks (Lencer and Trillenberg, 2008; McDowell et al., 2008). Matched control conditions allow higher order functions of interest to be isolated. Task demands are simple, minimizing effects on education level or IQ. Finally, performance on oculomotor tasks can be reliably measured across time (Ettinger et al., 2003), and are thus suitable for comparisons between drug and placebo.

To date, MPH effects on eye movements have been studied only in ADHD. Below we briefly review this literature focusing on visually-guided saccades, smooth pursuit, predictive saccades and antisaccades.

In the visually-guided saccade task the participant shifts gaze to keep an unpredictably and abruptly moving target on the fovea. Most studies find MPH to reduce saccade reaction times in ADHD (Klein et al., 2002; Munoz et al., 1999; O’Driscoll et al., 2005; but see Mostofsky et al., 2001) without affecting other variables.

Smooth pursuit is used to keep a slowly moving target on the fovea. Children with ADHD are not significantly impaired in pursuit (Castellanos et al., 2005; Jacobsen et al., 1996) but in the two available studies, MPH improved pursuit in this population (Bala et al., 1981; Bylsma and Pivik, 1989).

The predictive saccade task involves tracking a target that steps predictably and rhythmically in time and space. This task is thought to tap into motor planning and temporal processing (Joiner and Shelhamer, 2006; O’Driscoll et al., 2005). Predictive saccade performance is impaired in ADHD (Feifel et al., 2004; O’Driscoll et al., 2005). MPH significantly increases predictive saccades in ADHD when the direction and timing of the target movement is predictable but not when only the direction is predictable (O’Driscoll et al., 2005).

The antisaccade task is a commonly used measure of response inhibition. Participants fixating a central target must resist looking toward a suddenly appearing peripheral target, and instead look to the mirror position on the opposite side of the screen. Children with ADHD have elevated rates of antisaccade errors (Rommelse et al., 2008). There have been five studies of MPH effects on antisaccade performance in ADHD; three found MPH to reduce antisaccade errors (Klein et al., 2002; Munoz et al., 1999; O’Driscoll et al., 2005) and two found no effect on errors (Aman et al., 1998; Mostofsky et al., 2001). Four studies looked at correct antisaccade latency (Klein et al., 2002; Mostofsky et al., 2001; Munoz et al., 1999; O’Driscoll et al., 2005) and two of these found MPH to reduce correct antisaccade latency (Klein et al., 2002; O’Driscoll et al., 2005), while one found this effect for gap trials only (Munoz et al., 1999). Thus MPH has a variable effect on antisaccade errors and latency in ADHD.

An inverted-U relationship between baseline performance and MPH effects on cognition has been suggested in some studies (Engert et al., 2009; Mehta et al., 2000). This relationship means that in individuals with lower baseline performance MPH may improve cognition, while in individuals with normal performance at baseline, MPH could have no effect or even disrupt cognitive performance. Thus, MPH effects on eye movements in healthy adults could differ from those in ADHD.

No studies have examined the effect of MPH on oculomotor performance in healthy adults. In the current study, we examined the effects of MPH on visually-guided saccades, smooth pursuit, predictive saccades and antisaccades. If the effect of MPH is independent of baseline performance, effects should be similar to those seen in ADHD, that is, MPH should reduce visually-guided saccade latency, improve smooth pursuit, increase predictive saccades when target movement is completely predictable but not when only direction is predictable, and potentially reduce antisaccade errors and latency. However, if an inverted-U applies, then in healthy adults MPH effects may vary as a function of baseline performance, with initially better-performing participants showing no improvement or performance decrements.

sec.title: Subjects
sec.p: Twenty-nine healthy, Caucasian males (age 26.2 ± 5.3 years) took part in the study. Participants underwent a medical exam and were free of current physical illness as well as a history of DSM-III Axis I diagnoses as assessed by the Diagnostic Interview Schedule Screening Interview (DISSI) (Marcus et al., 1990). Additional exclusion criteria included drug use as determined by a urine test (Triage Screen for Drugs of Abuse, Biosite Diagnostics, San Diego, CA) and a first-degree relative with a diagnosis of schizophrenia or ADHD. Participants had normal or corrected-to-normal vision (Snellen chart). The study was approved by the Research Ethics Board of the McGill University Department of Psychology and the Institutional Review Board of the Douglas Mental Health University Institute. Participants provided written informed consent and were compensated for their time.

sec.title: Eye movements
sec.p: Tasks were presented on a 17-inch RGB monitor running at 135 Hz in a darkened room. The stimulus was a square subtending 0.5 × 0.5 degrees of visual angle presented on a black background. Eye movements were recorded from the dominant eye with an infrared pupil tracker (250 Hz) (Eyelink, SR Research, Mississauga, Ontario, Canada). Calibration was performed across 24° with a drift correction prior to each trial.

sec.title: Visually-guided saccades
sec.p: The target was presented in the center of the monitor for 1000–2000 ms then stepped horizontally to one of four peripheral locations (±6º, ±12º) where it remained for 1000ms (Ettinger et al., 2003). Each target location was presented 15 times in a random sequence. Dependent variables were saccade latency (ms), amplitude (degree) and peak velocity (degree/s).

sec.title: Smooth pursuit
sec.p: A target moved horizontally at 0.4 Hz across 24º of visual angle with a sinusoidal velocity profile (Dépatie et al., 2002). Participants were instructed to keep their gaze on the target. They performed four 30s blocks of pursuit. In two blocks, participants were asked to attend to a letter presented at the center of the target and press a button whenever it changed (monitoring condition). This manipulation enhances pursuit quality (Sweeney et al., 1994). In two blocks, the target center did not change (no-monitoring condition). Dependent variables were pursuit gain (eye velocity/target velocity) and the total number of saccades (O’Driscoll and Callahan, 2008).

sec.title: Predictive saccades
sec.p: Participants tracked a target as it stepped at a frequency of 0.4Hz between -12º, 0º, and +12º. Four conditions were administered that manipulated the predictability of the direction and timing of target movement: completely predictable, direction predictable, timing predictable and a saccade control condition (Gagnon et al., 2002). Direction of target movement from center was unpredictable in two conditions, but direction from the periphery (back to center) was always predictable. For conditions in which target timing was predictable, the duration of the target at each location was 625ms; otherwise, duration averaged 625 ms but varied between 500 and 750 ms. Each condition lasted 60s. Dependent variables were the percentage of predictive saccades (i.e. latency < 70ms) and the latency, amplitude and peak velocity of both predictive and reflexive saccades.

sec.title: Antisaccades
sec.p: This task was identical to the visually-guided saccade task except that participants were instructed to direct their gaze away from the peripheral target to the mirror location on the opposite side of the screen. Dependent variables were the percentage of errors, and the latency, amplitude and peak velocity of correct antisaccades.

sec.title: Physiological measures
sec.p: Blood pressure and pulse were measured immediately before capsule administration, and immediately before and after oculomotor testing. Samples of venous blood were taken immediately before and ≈ 2 h after capsule administration to calculate drug blood plasma levels.

sec.title: Procedures
sec.p: Participants first underwent a screening session to determine eligibility and performed the tasks to reduce practice effects on the medication trial (O’Driscoll et al., 2005). Participants also completed a number of self-report measures, the results of which have been reported elsewhere (Ettinger et al., 2006).

A double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover trial was then administered approximately one week after the screening session with medication order (placebo or methylphenidate first) randomized across subjects. Upon arrival at the lab, a breathalyzer (Alco-Sensor IV, Intoximeters, Inc., Saint Louis, MO) and urine drug screen (Triage Screen for Drugs of Abuse, Biosite Diagnostics, San Diego, CA) were administered. Vital signs were assessed by a nurse before capsule administration (T0), immediately before task performance (T1 – i.e. 50 minutes post-capsule administration) and immediately after task performance (T2 – i.e. approximately 90 minutes post-capsule). On one occasion, a sample of venous blood was taken for DNA extraction. The genetic analyses have been reported elsewhere (Ettinger et al., 2006).

MPH (20mg, average dose 0.26 mg/kg) and placebo were administered orally in identical capsules. This dose is clinically relevant and has improved cognition in healthy individuals in previous studies without inducing negative side effects (e.g. Camp-Bruno and Herting, 1994; Elliott et al., 1997).
Placebo and drug sessions took place between six and 11 days apart (mode seven days) with testing conducted at the same time on both days.

sec.title: Eye movement coding
sec.p: Eye movements were parsed with a semi-automated custom analysis software package (SR Research, Osgoode, ON) and checked visually. Saccades were identified based on velocity (>22°/s) and acceleration (>4000°/s2) criteria. Saccades were excluded from analyses according to published criteria (Dépatie et al., 2002); saccades with latency <70 ms were retained in the predictive saccade analyses (Gagnon et al., 2002). In the predictive saccade task, for each target step, the first saccade > 3° in the direction of the target was selected. For the pursuit task, the first half cycle for all blocks was excluded as were blinks and the portion of the pursuit trace 200 ms before and after blinks. Analyses of pursuit excluded the turnaround.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Data were winsorized, such that values > 3SD from the mean were replaced with the closest value, a process that retains rank order while removing the influence of extreme outliers. Analyses were conducted using PASW 18 statistical software (SPSS Inc.). Variables were assessed for normality using a one-sample Kolmogorov–Smirnov test; non-parametric tests were used for variables that were not normally distributed.

Eye movement variables were analyzed using two-way mixed ANOVAs with Drug as the within-subject factor, and Order as the between-subjects factor. For the smooth pursuit task, Condition (monitoring versus no monitoring) and Trace Half (first versus second half of each 30 second trace) were included as within-subject factors. Order effects are mentioned only when significant. For the predictive saccade tasks, Saccade Type (predictive versus reflexive) was also included as a within-subject factor. Expected main effects of saccade type on amplitude and peak velocity were obtained but are not reported except where they interacted with Group or Drug.

To investigate the possibility of an inverted-U response to MPH, participants were dichotomized into high/low performance at baseline using a median split of each of the major dependent variables. The two groups formed by baseline performance on a given task were then used as a between-subject factor in the analyses of that task.

For variables that showed a significant effect of MPH, we evaluated whether or not the magnitude of change in performance on the task was related to the magnitude of change in performance on other tasks, using Pearson’s r.

Mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) was calculated using the formula MAP = BPdia + 1/3 (BPsys – BPdia), where BPdia is diastolic blood pressure and BPsys is systolic blood pressure. MAP and heart rate were analyzed separately using mixed ANOVA models with Time (T0, T1 and T2) and Drug (methylphenidate, placebo) as within-subject factors and Order (methylphenidate-first, placebo-first) as the between-subject factor. Effects of Time are reported if they interact with Drug.
Data are reported as mean ± standard deviation in descriptive statistics. Statistical tests were two tailed.

sec.title: Visually-guided saccade task
sec.p: Latency of visually-guided saccades decreased significantly on MPH (Drug: F(1,25)= 9.8, p=0.004; Placebo 166.1± 20.4; MPH: 159.7 ± 18.6). Amplitude and peak velocity of visually-guided saccades were not changed by Drug (p>0.2).

sec.title: Smooth pursuit
sec.p: MPH significantly increased pursuit gain (Drug: F(1,27)=21.1, p<0.001; Placebo: 0.92±0.04 MPH:0.94±0.03) and decreased the number of saccades during pursuit (Drug: F(1,24)=18.2, p<0.001; Placebo: 27.6± 6.7, MPH: 23.4± 6.5). (Figure 1) (Saccade rate (number of saccades/seconds of data) yielded the same results). Smooth pursuit was poorer in the second half of each trace, with lower gain and more saccades in the second half of the trace than the first (Task Half on Gain, F(1,27)=13.5, p=0.001; Task Half on Saccades: F(1,27) = 27.7, p<0.001). However, Drug did not interact with Task Half; thus, MPH did not improve pursuit by preventing a decline in performance with time.

caption.p: Effect of MPH on smooth pursuit. Data are mean ± SE. Methylphenidate (MPH) significantly increased pursuit gain and decreased the number of saccades during pursuit.

sec.title: Completely predictable task
sec.p: Percentage of predictive saccades significantly increased with MPH (Drug, F(1,26) = 10.2, p=0.004; Placebo: 65.9%±22.3%, MPH: 74.1%±14.6%) (Figure 2).

caption.p: Effect of methylphenidate (MPH) on predictive saccades. Data are mean ± SE. MPH significantly increased the percentage of predictive saccades in conditions with predictable timing (completely predictable task (CPT) and timing predictable task (TPT)) but not in conditions without predictable timing (direction predictable task (DPT) and saccade control task (SCT)).

sec.p: For saccade latency, there was a three-way interaction between Drug, Saccade Type and Order (F(1,26) = 5.0, p = 0.034). This interaction reflected the fact that for reflexive saccades, but not for predictive saccades, drug-placebo differences were larger when MPH was received second (Placebo: 115.6±18.0, MPH:104.3±11.2) than when it was received first (Placebo: 108.2±16.6, MPH: 111.6±17.1, Drug by Order F(1,26)=5.12, p=0.032). Participants in the two orders did not differ in their reflexive or predictive saccade latencies on or off drug, or in session 1 or session 2.
Saccade amplitudes were unaffected by Drug.
Peak velocity of saccades increased on MPH (Drug: F(1,26)=7.7, p=0.01; MPH: 416.9±59.2; Placebo: 399.6±63.0). There was no interaction with Saccade Type.

sec.title: Direction predictable task
sec.p: Percentage of predictive saccades did not change in this condition with MPH (p>0.8) (Figure 2). Saccade latencies in this task were also unaffected by Drug (p>0.2)

For saccade amplitude, there was a significant Drug by Saccade Type interaction (F(1,27)=6.5, p=0.016). This reflected the fact that MPH increased predictive saccade amplitude slightly (t(28)=-1.13, p=0.2; Placebo: 10.4±1.3, MPH: 10.7±1.2) while decreasing reflexive saccade amplitude slightly (t(28)=0.24, p=0.8, Placebo: 11.6±0.8, MPH: 11.5±0.9), although both effects were non-significant in post-hoc comparisons.

Peak velocity significantly increased on MPH (F(1,27)=8.6, p=0.007). This effect was qualified by a significant Drug × Saccade Type interaction (F(1,27)=17.6, p<0.001). MPH significantly increased predictive saccade peak velocity (t(28)=-3.7, p=0.001, Placebo: 349.4±69.6, MPH: 382.4±70.1) without affecting reflexive saccade peak velocity (t(28)=-1.25, p=0.2. Placebo: 425.02±56.7, MPH: 431.6±59.2).

sec.title: Timing predictable task
sec.p: Percentage of predictive saccades significantly increased on MPH compared with placebo in the timing predictable task (Drug: F(1,27) = 4.9, p=0.035; Placebo: 27.4% ± 17.4%, MPH: 31.8% ± 15.9%) (Figure 2). Saccade latency and amplitude were unaffected by Drug (p>0.09).

For peak velocity, there was a significant Drug by Saccade type interaction (F(1,25)=18.9, p<0.001) indicating that MPH significantly increased the peak velocity of predictive saccades (t(26)=-3.13, p=0.004; Placebo: 371.6±70.7, MPH: 401.4±68.1) without affecting that of reflexive saccades (t(28)=-0.28, p=0.8; Placebo: 435.8±61.5, MPH:437.5±53.6).

sec.title: Saccade control task
sec.p: In the control task, percentage of predictive saccades did not change with MPH (p>0.16) (Figure 2).

For latency, there was a three-way interaction of Drug, Saccade Type and Order (F(1,25)=4.6, p=0.042). This reflected the fact that predictive saccades but not reflexive saccades were more temporally accurate in the second session than the first, regardless of which pill was administered (i.e. practice effect) (Pred Sac Latency first session: -50.3±62; second session -28.9 ±59.7; paired t(26)=, p= 0.038). When the target was in the periphery about to move back to the center, participants would sometimes anticipate the move, making a predictive saccade. Increased exposure to the target allowed anticipations in the second session to be more accurate than those in the first, without affecting their number, and without affecting reflexive saccades.
For saccade amplitude, there was no effect of Drug.

For peak velocity, there was a Drug by Saccade Type interaction (F(1,25)=6.33, p=0.019). MPH significantly increased the peak velocity of predictive saccades (t(26)-2.42, p=0.02; Placebo: 361.8±85.7, MPH: 393.6±65.7) without affecting the peak velocity of reflexive saccades (t(26)= -0.57, p=0.57; Placebo: 431.4±60.2, MPH: 434.8±52.6).

sec.title: Antisaccades
sec.p: There were no significant effects of Drug on antisaccade errors, latency, amplitude or peak velocity (ps > 0.1) (Table 1).

fn.p: Data represent mean ± SD. Significant MPH-placebo comparisons are in bold. VGS: visually-guided saccade task; Pursuit: smooth pursuit task. CPT: completely predictable task; DPT: direction predictable task; TPT: timing predictable task; SCT: saccade control task; AntiS: antisaccade task; MPH: methylphenidate; P: on placebo; D: on drug. Reflexive and Predictive refer to different saccade types generated in each condition (see Methods and materials).

sec.title: Drug response as a function of baseline performance
sec.p: There were no significant Group by Drug interactions (all ps > 0.1). Thus, drug effects did not depend on baseline performance.

sec.title: Correlations
sec.p: The magnitude of change was calculated for each subject for variables that changed significantly with MPH (visually-guided saccade latency, smooth pursuit gain and total saccades during pursuit, proportion of predictive saccades in the completely predictable and timing predictable tasks, and peak velocity of predictive saccades). The only significant correlation was between change in smooth pursuit gain and change in the number of saccades on this task (r = -0.57, p = 0.001).

sec.title: Physiological variables
sec.p: For MAP and for Heart Rate, there was no effect of Drug. Heart rates were higher on the first day of testing (Drug × Order: F(1,26)=5.09, p=0.03); thus, in those who received placebo first, heart rate declined on MPH (Day 2) (Placebo: 66.4±7.8, MPH: 64.5±7.6), while in those who received MPH first, heart rate declined on Placebo (Day 2) (Placebo: 68.8±7.8, MPH: 71.8±7.6).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our results provide the first evidence of MPH effects on oculomotor function in healthy controls. Our principal findings were that MPH: 1) decreased saccade latency in the visually-guided saccade task; 2) improved smooth pursuit performance; 3) increased the proportion of predictive saccades in conditions where target timing was predictable; 4) increased the peak velocity of predictive saccades in the predictive saccade task, generally without affecting the peak velocity of reflexive saccades; and 5) had no effect on antisaccade performance. The general pattern of MPH effects in healthy adults is similar to that seen in children with ADHD. A possible exception was the antisaccade task where MPH had no effect in healthy adults, whereas in some studies of ADHD it has improved inhibition.

MPH-related reductions of visually-guided saccade latency could reflect the drug’s action in the caudate nucleus. MPH’s primary site of action is the striatum, where it binds to the DA transporter (Ding et al., 1997; Volkow et al., 1995), increasing DA levels (Volkow et al., 2001). The caudate is involved in saccadic reaction time through a series of connections that gate firing in the motor output layers of the superior colliculus (Hikosaka and Wurtz, 1983; Hikosaka et al., 2000; Jayaraman et al., 1977). In the direct pathway, activation of the caudate inhibits the substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNpr) which tonically inhibits the output layers of the superior colliculus; thus, in this pathway, caudate activation releases the SC from tonic inhibition and facilitates saccade release (Hikosaka et al., 2000). Consistent with this, shorter saccadic reaction times are associated with higher caudate neuron activity in non-human primates (Hikosaka et al., 2000; Itoh et al., 2003; Watanabe and Munoz, 2009; Watanabe et al., 2003). Although alerting effects could also be invoked to explain the change in visually-guided saccade latency, alerting has been reported to reduce latencies of both prosaccades and antisaccades (Kristjansson et al., 2004), which was not the pattern observed here.

Peak velocity changes with MPH could also be attributed to drug action on DA in basal ganglia. Increasing basal ganglia activity in non-human primates has been reported to increase peak velocity of saccades and to have a greater effect on voluntary than on reflexive saccades (Hikosaka and Wurtz, 1985; Kori et al., 1995), consistent with what we found here. A greater effect of dopamine manipulations on voluntary saccades has also been reported in humans (Straube et al., 1999). In non-human primates, peak velocity can be increased and saccade latency decreased by reward (Kawagoe et al., 1998; Takikawa et al., 2002) and these changes have been shown to be modulated by dopamine in the caudate (Nakamura and Hikosaka, 2006). MPH-related changes in saccade kinetics resemble reward-related changes and may have similar neural substrates.

The MPH-induced improvement in smooth pursuit in healthy adults is consistent with two previous studies in ADHD (Bala et al., 1981; Bylsma and Pivik, 1989). In controls, MPH effects on pursuit have not been studied but dextroamphetamine, which is similar pharmacologically, has not affected pursuit. However, the only studies done had very low power (five and 11 participants) (Malaspina et al., 1994; Tedeschi et al., 1983). Nicotine, which increases DA indirectly (Imperato et al., 1986; Pierce and Kumaresan, 2006), has had similar effects on pursuit in controls to what we find here with MPH (i.e. increased gain, reduced saccades (Dépatie et al., 2002; Domino et al., 1997; Sherr et al., 2002; but see also Olincy et al., 1998)).

In the predictive saccade task, MPH increased the proportion of predictive saccades selectively in conditions in which timing was predictable. (The direction of Target steps from the periphery was back to center so some predictive saccades could be made in all conditions). The MPH-related increases in predictive saccades could reflect an effect on timing since the subject can use temporal information to better synchronize saccade release with target movement. MPH administration has been reported to improve performance in some subsecond timing tasks in ADHD. For example, MPH has improved performance on the predictive saccade task (O’Driscoll et al., 2005), on manual measures of sensorimotor synchronization (Rubia et al., 2003) and on a finger tapping task in which subjects were required to generate movements at a specified rhythm (Ben-Pazi et al., 2006).

Subsecond timing is thought to be supported by the basal ganglia and cerebellum (Wiener et al., 2010) and both these regions are involved in predictive saccades (Gagnon et al., 2002). Patients with cerebellar involvement show reduced ability to use predictable timing to shorten saccade latency (Isotalo et al., 1995; Nagel and Zangemeister, 2003; Sailer et al., 2005; but see Lasker et al., 2005) and imaging studies in humans highlight the importance of cerebellum in timing predictable saccade tasks (Gagnon et al., 2002; O’Driscoll et al., 2000; Simó et al., 2005). With respect to basal ganglia, evidence of deficits in predictive saccade timing in Parkinson’s patients is mixed (Crawford et al., 1989; O’Sullivan et al., 1997; Ventre et al., 1992), but putamen is significantly activated during fully predictive and timing predictable saccades (Gagnon et al., 2002). A recent study in monkeys found neurons in caudate to encode time periods ranging from 150 to 500 ms when saccades were performed without explicit timing requirements (Jin et al., 2009).

The effects of MPH on timing performance might be mediated via action on the cerebellum. MPH increases blood flow and glucose metabolism in cerebellum in healthy adults (Mehta et al., 2000; Udo de Haes, et al., 2007; Volkow et al., 1997) and in individuals with ADHD (Anderson et al., 2002; Matochik et al., 1993; Schweitzer et al., 2003), possibly through action on DA. The ventral tegmental area has extensive projections to the granule and Purkinje cell layers of the cerebellum (Ikai et al., 1992; Simon et al., 1979), which have DA receptors (Khan et al., 1998). Dopamine transporter (DAT) immunoreactive axons have also been found in the vermis of the primate cerebellum (Melchitzky and Lewis, 2000), a brain area involved in eye movements.

Few studies have looked at the behavioral effect of cerebellar DA. In rats, microinjections of DA agonists and antagonists into the cerebellum activate or inhibit locomotor activity in a dose dependent manner (Barik and de Beaurepaire, 1996; Kolasiewicz et al., 2008). The distribution of DA receptors in the cerebellum suggests that this neurotransmitter may modulate cerebellar long-term depression, which plays an important role in motor timing (Alder and Barbas, 1995; Kim et al., 2009; Schweighofer et al., 2004). Both DA and NA modulate climbing fiber firing, which impacts long-term depression and long-term potentiation (Carey and Regehr, 2009).

MPH did not affect antisaccades. Previous studies of ADHD suggested MPH might reduce antisaccade latencies (Klein et al., 2002; Munoz et al., 1999; O’Driscoll et al., 2005) and errors (Aman et al., 1998; Mostofsky et al., 2001; Munoz et al., 1999; O’Driscoll et al., 2005), although results are divided. In an earlier study, we found that dextroamphetamine reduced antisaccade errors and also affected latency as a function of baseline performance (Allman et al., 2010). These effects were not observed here with MPH. Differences in the findings for the two drugs could reflect differences in the antisaccade tasks used. In previous studies only one target location was used in each hemifield. In the current study, we used two per hemifield. Additional target locations affect saccade latency and error rate (Bell et al., 2000; Delaney and Roberts, 1999; Evdokimidis et al., 2006; Smyrnis et al., 2002). The requirement to attend to more potential target locations could affect the role of DA in the task by shifting the cognitive balance away from a focus on internal goals to guide behavior toward the need to flexibly attend to environmental events (Bilder et al., 2004; Seamans and Yang, 2004). These competing cognitive states are thought to differentially involve D1 versus D2 receptors and tonic versus phasic DA release, and could influence drug effects on task performance.

A strength but also a limitation of the current study is the homogeneity of the sample. Because this was the first study of MPH effects on eye movements in healthy adults, we chose a homogeneous group to decrease population-related variance that might reduce drug-related signal. As a result, the extent to which the results apply to females, other racial groups and other age ranges is unclear. An additional limitation of the study was the use of a single, low dose of MPH. It is possible that at a higher dose, an interaction between baseline performance and drug response might have been observed, or that cognitive effects that were not obtained might have been found. However, the dose we used has been shown to significantly increase extracellular dopamine in healthy adults (Volkow et al., 2004) and to affect other aspects of neuropsychological performance in previous studies of young adults (Camp-Bruno and Hertig, 1994; Elliott et al., 1997).

To conclude, low dose MPH significantly improves some cognitive and motor functions in adults with intact baseline performance. MPH effects in healthy adults were similar to those observed in ADHD. The selective improvements in predictive saccade conditions with predictable timing is consistent with MPH-related improvements in timing functions.

fn.p: This work was supported by an NSERC Doctoral Fellowship and an NSERC Julie Payette Master’s Award (AA), a Tomlinson Postdoctoral Fellowship from McGill University (UE), a grant from the GW Stairs Memorial Fund (UE), a William Dawson Scholar Award (GO’D), an operating grant from the CIHR (GO’D) (Grant number MOP-44061) and funding from the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (ET 31/2-1) (UE).
